awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Biogenic Volatile Organic Compounds (BVOC)  Distributions across the Amazon Basin during the Chemistry of the Amazon-Field Experiment (CAFE) Campaign
awd_abstract_narration:
This RAPID project is focused on quantifying and improving knowledge about the processes that control variations in the surface-layer concentrations of gases emitted from vegetation in the Amazon. American scientists will take advantage of the January 2023 Brazilian-led Chemistry of the Amazon - Field Experiment in Brazil (CAFE-BRAZIL) river cruise to collect observations of isoprene and other biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC) along a transect from the central to northwestern Amazon. As the biosphere is the dominant source of the organic gases in the atmosphere that interact with anthropogenic pollution to form ozone and secondary aerosol, the ultimate societal benefit of this project will be an improved ability to assess the total impact of human activities on climate and air quality.

The primary objectives of this project are to: 1) quantify isoprene and other BVOC diurnal and spatial variations from central to northwestern Amazon; 2) relate BVOC variations to climate and land cover; and 3) use the results to improve the MEGAN BVOC emission model predictability of processes controlling BVOC emission and their response to climate change. A mechanistic understanding of these processes could transform the approaches used to model isoprene and other BVOC emissions in the Amazon tropical rainforest and other highly biodiverse ecosystems. The data collected during this project will increase the understanding of biological processes that control the variations and distributions of gaseous emissions from vegetation in the Amazon, and improve model predictions of ecosystem responses to climate change.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Facilities development: This study demonstrated the utility of using the Amazon State University (UEA: Universidad del Estado del Amazonas) river boat research facility to successfully sample biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOCs) across large regions of Amazonia. Understanding BVOC emissions is important because these compounds influence climate and air quality. This had previously been accomplished only with relatively expensive aircraft sampling platforms. The research boat facility was demonstrated to be suitable for both large equipment, in this case a Proton Transfer Reaction Mass Spectrometry (PTRMS), as well as small relatively inexpensive sorbent cartridges that were shipped to the U.S. for analysis by Thermal Desorption Gas Chromatography with Time-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry and Flame Ionization detectors (TD-GC-TOFMS/FID). Issues such as boat engine exhaust were identified and approaches for minimizing interferences and filtering data were developed.

Field Campaign: VOC and other atmospheric constituents were measured along an 800 km gradient extending from the central Amazon Basin (Manaus, Brazil) to the Western Amazon (Sao Gabriel da Cachoeira, a region where there is almost data on BVOC. Each location was sampled twice, once on the upriver segment and then again on the downriver.

Significant results: The results show that there are considerable differences in the BVOC concentrations in the unstudied western Amazon compared to the central Amazon. The BVOC concentrations followed the expected diurnal behavior of higher concentrations in daytime and periods of higher sunlight and temperature. Monoterpenes followed the expected diurnal pattern for tropical forests, with higher concentrations in daytime, but there were substantial regional differences in the isoprene to monoterpene ratio. As expected, isoprene was the dominant BVOC in all parts of the Amazon Basin. Camphene, a-pinene and limonene were the dominant monoterpenes observed.
